title: 1968-G1
statement: G1. Division + LCP (easy version)time limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputThis is the easy version of the problem. In this version $$$l=r$$$.You are given a string $$$s$$$. For a fixed $$$k$$$, consider a division of $$$s$$$ into exactly $$$k$$$ continuous substrings $$$w_1,\\dots,w_k$$$. Let $$$f_k$$$ be the maximal possible $$$LCP(w_1,\\dots,w_k)$$$ among all divisions.$$$LCP(w_1,\\dots,w_m)$$$ is the length of the Longest Common Prefix of the strings $$$w_1,\\dots,w_m$$$.For example, if $$$s=abababcab$$$ and $$$k=4$$$, a possible division is $$$\\color{red}{ab}\\color{blue}{ab}\\color{orange}{abc}\\color{green}{ab}$$$. The $$$LCP(\\color{red}{ab},\\color{blue}{ab},\\color{orange}{abc},\\color{green}{ab})$$$ is $$$2$$$, since $$$ab$$$ is the Longest Common Prefix of those four strings. Note that each substring consists of a continuous segment of characters and each character belongs toexactlyone substring.Your task is to find $$$f_l,f_{l+1},\\dots,f_r$$$.In this version $$$l=r$$$.InputThe first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 10^4$$$) — the number of test cases.The first line of each test case contains two integers $$$n$$$, $$$l$$$, $$$r$$$ ($$$1 \\le l = r \\le n \\le 2 \\cdot 10^5$$$) — the length of the string and the given range.The second line of each test case contains string $$$s$$$ of length $$$n$$$, all characters are lowercase English letters.It is guaranteed that the sum of $$$n$$$ over all test cases does not exceed $$$2\\cdot 10^5$$$.OutputFor each test case, output $$$r-l+1$$$ values: $$$f_l,\\dots,f_r$$$.ExampleInput73 3 3aba3 3 3aaa7 2 2abacaba9 4 4abababcab10 1 1codeforces9 3 3abafababa5 3 3zpozpOutput0 1 3 2 10 2 0NoteIn the first sample $$$n=k$$$, so the only division of $$$aba$$$ is $$$\\color{red}a\\color{blue}b\\color{orange}a$$$. The answer is zero, because those strings do not have a common prefix.In the second sample, the only division is $$$\\color{red}a\\color{blue}a\\color{orange}a$$$. Their longest common prefix is one.

processed.result:
You are given a string $s$ of length $n$.  You need to find the longest common prefix length ($LCP$) for all possible divisions of the string into $k$ substrings, where $l \le k \le r$.

* $LCP(w_1, w_2, ..., w_m)$ is the length of the longest common prefix of the strings $w_1, w_2, ..., w_m$.

For example, if $s = "abababcab"$ and $k = 4$, one possible division is:

* $w_1 = "ab$", $w_2 = "ab$", $w_3 = "abc$", $w_4 = "ab"$

The $LCP(w_1, w_2, w_3, w_4)$ is $2$ because the longest common prefix of these four strings is "ab".

You need to find the $LCP$ for all possible divisions of the string into $k$ substrings, where $l \le k \le r$.  

**Input:**

* The first line contains an integer $t$ ($1 \le t \le 10^4$) - the number of test cases.
* For each test case:
    * The first line contains three integers $n$, $l$, and $r$ ($1 \le l = r \le n \le 2 \cdot 10^5$) - the length of the string and the range of $k$.
    * The second line contains the string $s$ of length $n$.

**Output:**

For each test case, output $r-l+1$ values: $f_l, f_{l+1}, ..., f_r$.
You are given a string.  Find the longest common prefix of all possible ways to divide the string into a given number of parts.  You need to do this for a range of part counts.
